body.p:
Your kind consoling
favor I received and feel grateful for
the interest so ? manifested. I was
not mistaken being perfectly aware that
a period of my life so full of sorrow, would
not have passed unnoticed by you; for
surely in minds correct, time and dis-
tance cannot blunt those essentials
in our nature so wisely and benignly
mingled therewith by a Divine Hand. I as-
sure you my friend I have oft wished
you could have known my revered moth-
er; a life of piety and general benevolence
was hers. Left a young widow she carefully
trained her children by the blessed light
of Revelation of which she was so devoted a

p.rend: The following line is written sideways in the left margin

body.p: I forgot to state that I had received $15 from Uncle

a follower to her last hours. When I reflect
on the purity of her life and the sacred hope
of a blessed future I feel all the consolation
allowed to poor mortals. Again when mundane
rivers force themselves on the mind, all my philo-
sophy vanishes yielding to that natural impulse
so keenly harrowing my soul; yet I feel that
such is not ungracious in the sight of
Heaven; they are to my mind sacred, the tears
of febal piety cannot be at ?; I am brand-
ed for this by those around me; but they little
know my views. My attachment to my beloved
parent was of so sacred a nature that all who
observe the blissful cord which bound our souls
can weep with me, and not condem the tears of
holiness. By my ? you will find that
we have just been celebrating the Passover
and I fervently hope that you have been more
happily spending it in your usual plase and
at the head of affairs. I have not time
for all the particulars of myself, I can ? wish but
my good Uncle to whom I have the honor

of introducing you, will give you such as may as
an old friend interest you. I hope you will
in my name as well as your own introduce
him to Miss Gratz, delicacy prevents me do-
ing so myself as I have not written to her
for so long a time. Be kind enough to tell
her so for me and in your best manner
Mrs Florance also, and with kind love
to all. I am sorry to find you so cool
with my friends Miss and Mrs Hart, tis not
well of to be so distant with all, you must
try to keep friends. You know not how worrily
my poor old Uncle advocates your cause
and the same lively interest ? for you.
Let me hear all particulars as the report
here is that you and the congregation have
come to an arrangement. All apply to
me for information, but alas I can give
none as your communications are
so few and far between. Wait not
for letters, when matters of so much
interest to yourself and friends are on
the carpet. Tell my friend Mrs Cozens I

often think of her with affection and am
quite happy to hear that I am not forgotten.
I have not had a line from Louisa though I
wrote her of the sad event. Ms Hart was very
fraught and I assure you I highly appreciate
it. I hope to be able to write by Uncle if
not tell her how much I regret the inability,
and but will not keep her long without a
few lines. To our friends generally
I hope you will introduce Uncle, he
has several letters to strangers, one from
the Counsel, and other merchants also some
private letters.—You will greatly oblige
me by having a Watch repaired, which I
shall send by Uncle, and be kind enough to
send it by Sal Delo?. I require also a
few books a list of which I will and if in
time to do so, if not in my next (God willing)
Grandfather has been for some days quite un
well, expects to be operated on in a few
days; Heaven grant him success; he seems very
sanguine and needful? about it. Remember me
to all friends and accept the continued regard of yours
